clinical_study.brief_title: An Adaptive, Sequential Evaluation of Powered and Manual Circular Staplers in Left-Sided Colorectal Anastomoses
clinical_study.official_title: An Adaptive, Sequential Evaluation of Powered and Manual Circular Staplers in Left-Sided Colorectal Anastomoses

brief_summary.textblock: This prospective clinical study will compare a powered circular stapler to commercial mechanical staplers for performance issues in patients scheduled to undergo colectomy with left-sided colon anastomosis.

detailed_description.textblock:
Surgical staplers have been utilized in colorectal procedures since the early 20th century, with intraluminal staplers used to create the anastomosis since 1979. Successful utilization of these devices, whether in open or laparoscopic procedures, requires extensive training and experience. Even with experience, device issues such as stapler misfire, incomplete firing, low surgeon satisfaction, etc., may occur. In a retrospective study of 349 colorectal resections, 67 (19%) procedures had some type of technical error. The most frequently reported issues from the analysis were positive leak tests, difficulty placing or removing the stapler, and inadequate donuts. Surgeons may also experience psychological or physical stress during procedures due to complications, workload, or other factors.
Patients scheduled to undergo a left-sided colon resection, and who meet study entry criteria, may be enrolled. Investigators will perform each procedure using either a commercially-available manual or powered circular stapler according to their instructions for use (IFU). There will be no blinding. Procedures may be performed open or via minimally invasive surgery (MIS) according to institutional standard-of-care (SOC). Use of a hand port and robotic assistance are permissible providing an intra-luminal circular stapler is used to create the anastomosis. Conversion from laparoscopic to open surgery is permissible under the protocol at the surgeon's discretion for the patient's safety.
The study will be conducted using a staged approach. In Stage 1, surgeons will perform procedures according to institutional SOC using their preferred manual circular stapler. Surgeons will begin using the powered circular stapler (Stage 2) after procedures with the manual stapler have been completed. Surgeons will complete approximately the same number of procedures with the powered stapler as were completed with the manual stapler.
The final scheduled study visit will occur approximately 3-5 weeks post-procedure (routinely scheduled follow-up with surgeon). Follow-up by phone is permissible when an on-site visit is not planned or is more than six weeks post-operative.

clinical_study.why_stopped: The study has been temporarily suspended due to device availability.

primary_outcome.description: Defined as failure of the circular stapler (manual or powered device) to meet performance specifications for use.
